body:
update:

----
preview of hive table is very fast and works fine, but when i want to query it using chart or sql editor
things go wrong.   query never ends...

truely some mis-understanding here
in manual there is an example of using "  jdbc+hive://  " as prefix of uri

but actucully just " hive:// " is needed for hive datasource, otherwise error will be prompted like posted.
need to correct the manual i think ?

a quick visual tour of the things that this PR changes:

### Initial list of dashboards
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9629830/39720733-8f858688-51fa-11e8-96c9-fe01ba76743e.png)

### After John publishes his secret dashboard

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9629830/39720891-f0b34800-51fa-11e8-8c3a-941bd72813a5.png)

### Toggling the published status of a dashboard you own
![image](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Tresdon/misc_public/master/images/superset/toggle_status.gif)

### Trying to toggle the status of a dashboard you do not own
![image](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Tresdon/misc_public/master/images/superset/no_permission.gif)

Superset should provide either better documentation or some kind of way to override less/css files that get included with the build (as templates are easily overrideable/extendable). Essentially to theme Superset. The only way I'm seeing to do this is rolling something custom, which would be fine, except any css/less changes going forward would have to be manually applied/hard to maintain.

Hi, 

I have tried setting it up on Elastic Beanstalk. Initially ELB is throwing many errors as many of the pre-requisite tools that are required for deploying superset are not available when ELB tries to deploy the application. So, in order to overcome that, I had to use prehooks feature for ELB to install pre-requisites before actually AWS tries to deploy the application. 

This is what i have setup in .ebextensions folders 

01_pre_deps.config
`packages:
  yum:
    gcc: []
    gcc-c++: []
    libffi-devel: []`

91_update_env.config
`files:
  "/opt/elasticbeanstalk/hooks/preinit/91_update_env.sh":
    mode: "000755"
    owner: root
    group: root
    content: |
      #!/usr/bin/env bash
      yum install gcc gcc-c++ libffi-devel python-devel python-pip python-wheel openssl-devel libsasl2-devel openldap-devel cyrus-sasl-devel.x86_64`

99_init_superset.config
`files:
  "/opt/elasticbeanstalk/hooks/appdeploy/post/99_init_superset.sh":
    mode: "000755"
    owner: root
    group: root
    content: |
      #!/usr/bin/env bash
      . /opt/python/run/venv/bin/activate
      fabmanager create-admin --app superset --username admin --password admin --firstname admin --lastname admin --email admin@gma.com
      superset db upgrade
      superset load_examples
      superset init
      gunicorn -w 4 -k gevent --timeout 120 -b  0.0.0.0:443 --limit-request-line 0 --limit-request-field_size 0 --statsd-host localhost:8088 superset:app wsgi & `

After doing the above, I was able to get the environment up and running but on AWS Beanstalk AWS automatically does a health check and deletes an instance if it finds the instance health is not right. 

For the ELB environment that's being setup for superset, AWS is continuously failing health checks and it's invoking EC2 instances replacement due to which i wasn't able to get a stable ELB env up and running. 

I need to find out why health checks are failing on AWS EC2 instances invoked by ELB and if that's resolved, then should be able to bring up stable env on ELB. 

Thanks

> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-superset/pull/4948?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [f21ba1a...168acb4](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-superset/pull/4948?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).
You'll have to export from the newer version as well as we moved away from using pickles in favor or `json` for security reasons.

Happy to add these 2 options to the list, but note that you can type free-form expression in the dropdown and it works: try `3 days`->`enter` and it will work. Most users don't figure that out on their own though, and 15-30 minutes are common timeframes so let's add them.
Anything in the logs? Is the database in async mode?
Are you sure your `superset_config.py` is found and doesn't fail? If you `print(MAPBOX_API_KEY)` in `superset_config.py` do you see the key?
Also if using gunicorn there's a subprocess involved so make sure to `export MAPBOX_API_KEY={secret}` so that it makes its way in subprocesses
How's the `Deck.gl Scatterplot` looking in `0.25.0` ?
You have to rely on the json parsing functions exposed by your database engine. For example when using Presto you'd leverage Presto's `json_extract` function. Which engine are you querying against?

`query_obj`  is hashed to define the caching key. If we'd pass the `form_data` in there, changing any control that does not affect the query (say `show_legend` for example) wouldn't hit the cache even though the query is the same. 

By providing `form_data` to the template, users can in theory use it to change the query template, meaning since we don't know in what way they may be doing this, or even which key in form_data they're using we really have to cache based on everything in `form_data`.

While we could allow this an still cache based on the hash disregarding `form_data` it may be intricately confusing to users.
Any specific reason to not follow the default "Squash and merge" ?

There no longer is `500 - Internal Server Error` with a stack trace rendered on the UI, which is good.

Now, when I stop a query after ~6s of its execution I
- sometimes get a yellow box saying "Query was stoped"
- sometimes get a red box saying "The query has been stopped"
- sometimes get a yellow box "Query was stoped" which then turns into a red box "The query has been stopped"

@Fokko Just did some tests, and in general it seems to be working! 

Some issues that we noticed but haven't investigated further:
* With the 3d graphs, the pitch and bear kept being reset to 0, so we haven't seen anything 3d yet
* Time/animation didn't seem properly pick up the available hours (perhaps caused by having more than MAX ROWS rows in a single hour)

(looping in @DonQueso89)

Oh interesting. In reality the configuration should be a logical `OR` here where you shouldn't have both options turned on. When I modeled it originally I had 2 buttons (`Run` and `Run Async`) but was told it was too confusing for users. Anyhow we should fix it so that async takes precedence over sync.

The workaround is to uncheck sync.
Uncheck `Autozoom` otherwise the viewport will be changed at each render. The idea with autozoom is to easily find your data and to allow for dashboard filter that zoom to the right location.
Rogue-merging this as I need to reference it in the release email.
Yes, also using py3.6 would fix this I believe.
This is related to the notes in https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/blob/master/UPDATING.md (the 3rd item)

>  logical OR here where you shouldn't have both options turned on.

I guess you meant XOR :)
So, why don't you make it a choice `execution_mode: {'sync', 'async'}`?

@mistercrunch thanks for referencing the update notes. I must admit i didn't read them.
I don't build from sources. Today I just `pip install superset==0.25.0` in a completely fresh env (+ some optional dependencies needed in my flow, like gevent, pyhive). Then I run `fabmanager` or `gunicorn superset:app` -- I don't have any specific version requirements for flask or sqlalchemy or anything else. How can i incorporate `pip install -r requirements.txt` in this flow?

Yup that's what we should do but I've been too lazy to write the database migration script and minor code logic changes required to do this. Also I don't think FAB has an easy way to have a string column represented as a `<select />`.

Easier would be to just deprecate the `sync` option.

Changed your mind? 😞

Looks like with the DBAPI driver and SQLAlchemy dialect most of the pieces of the puzzles are in place. Superset does need an extra thing though: an entry in db_engine_spec:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/blob/master/superset/db_engine_specs.py#L1317

The mechanism is a bit different.

I'm assuming you're using `PyHive` ?

The default setting is synchronous and applies only to SQL Lab (not to the "explore view"), this allows for long queries to be executed on a Superset worker as opposed to in a web request which will timeout depending on your configuration.
We don't support "row-level security" at the moment. You may be able to use views and/or templating to solve this.

The real error here is `cx_Oracle.OperationalError: ORA-03113: end-of-file on communication channel` and seems unrelated to Superset, and related to the SQLAlchemy dialect and/or the Oracle dbapi driver itself.
Thanks !!! I'll try that !
http://superset.apache.org/installation.html#configuration
Have you tried using the `engine_params` key in the extra JSON blob of the database configuration? It would look something like this: This should result in something much like in your python shell
Confirmed with the person who reported the problem offline that this fixes the issue. Mergin'

have you requested a kerberos' ticket? I had run a kinit before to connect, for getting the kerberos ticket. I can see in your error log the following message

`No kerberos credentials are availble
`
So it sounds like your user doesn't have any kerberos ticket
Try to run a kinit in the computer running the command is below (adapted to your user/environment):

`kinit your_domain_user@YOUR.FULLY.QUALIFIED.DOMAIN.COM`
Not fixed in 0.25.4 release with SQLalchemy 1.2.2

Okay, I figured it out. As I was mentioning earlier, it was trying to look for the Kerberos cache for the user 'root'. `No Kerberos credentials available (default cache: /tmp/krb5cc_0`. Got the hint from the file name since Kerberos cache tickets are usually appended with the gid of the user. In this case it is _0 which is for 'root'.

So the resolution is that, 

1.  All the below steps should be performed by a user who can authenticate itself against KDC and not some user like 'root'.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/34889904/39811956-65ea65fa-53a8-11e8-9456-8e817e94feea.png)

2. Using Impyla seemed to be more elegant than PyHive. Install `impyla` using pip as root.

`pip install impyla`

3. You need to have the keytab file for the user used in step1. Do a kinit using the same.

4. Configure the connection string in Superset something like this.

`SQLAlchemy URI = impala://<hive_host>:10000/default`

```Extra = {
    "metadata_params": {},
    "engine_params": {
		"connect_args": {
		    "auth_mechanism": "GSSAPI",
		    "kerberos_service_name":"hive"
		 }
}
}
```

5. If something goes wrong regarding the packages, you can connect to the Superset server and use the Python shell to ensure that the modules are working fine, this way:

```
from sqlalchemy import *
engine = sqlalchemy.create_engine('impala://<hive_host>:10000/default', connect_args={'auth_mechanism': 'GSSAPI','kerberos_service_name': 'hive'})
c = engine.connect()
result = c.execute('SELECT count(*) from my_table')
print result.fetchall()
```

Yes, I had the keytab file and did kinit as well. But the problem was I using the user 'root' to do the installation and start the server. Once I did with a user who was able to authenticate itself against Kerberos, I could connect to hive.

https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/issues/4951

which version of python and pip do you have? These are warnings from pypy.org which is the repository of python packages and completely unrelated to superset.

@jasnovak I can get the filter to work with this change OR the map to work, but not both at the same time. I can create two columns one to filter on and the other to group by. However, that is an ugly hack. Have you been successful with both working?

Also you may want to `pip install requirements.txt` from the repo prior to `pip install .` to install the pinned libs we test/build against.

Note that `pip install .` is somewhat equivalent but superior in many ways to `python setup.py install`. We should update the installation docs to reflect that.

Yes, we do both: we create a mapped column using an extraction function, and use it to filter. Do you click both the "groupable" and  "filterable" box when you create your column?

Also, perhaps there's something amiss in your definition? Try defining like this:

{
  "type": "extraction",
  "dimension": "country",
  "outputName": "country_group",
  "outputType": "STRING",
  "extractionFn": {
    "type": "lookup",
    "dimension": "dimensionName",
    "outputName": "dimensionOutputName",
    "replaceMissingValueWith": "missing_value",
    "retainMissingValue": false,
    "lookup": {
      "type": "map",
      "map": {
        "Algeria": "EMEA",
        "Faroe Islands": "EMEA",
        "Luxembourg": "EMEA",
        ...

@mistercrunch This pull request should be finished now, let me know what you think. One thing I didn't mention was that this doesn't get rid of the `self.has_all_datasource_access()` check on dashboards and it still validates that user has access to all charts in the particular dashboard if they don't have access to all datasources. So right now for gamma users this is an additional constraint on top of them having access to all charts which we may want to change.
